I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
1.  On September 27, 2017, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a loan of up to 
$30,000,000  and  an  equity  investment  of  $30,000,000  to  Ameriabank  CJSC  (AMB)  for 
Strengthening the Banking Sector for Financial Inclusion.1 The equity component has been fully 
disbursed while the loan agreement is expected to be signed in January 2019. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  AMB is the largest bank in Armenia in terms of assets, loan portfolio and profitability. AMB 
aims to increase its market share, diversify its loan book towards a larger share of SMEs and 
retail business, become the first universal bank in Armenia by 2020, and be the first Armenian 
bank to list on an international exchange. To achieve its strategic goals, AMB is in the process of 
implementing a comprehensive transformation program which focuses on five key areas: 
•  alignment of AMB’s business and operational model to development objectives and 
priorities; 
•  transformation into a digital bank for more efficient retail, micro and small business 
banking; 
•  enhancement of lending capacities by scaling rapid scoring-based decision making;  
•  strengthening AMB’s corporate governance, risk management and HR management 
systems; and 
•  development of innovation capacities and tools for effective transformation management.  
 
3.  The ADB TA contribution is a small part of AMB’s overall investment and AMB will be 
contributing more than three dollars from its own resources for every dollar of ADB funds spent. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
Output 1: Business Model Enhancement Study ($250,000) 
 
4.  AMB will engage a consulting firm to conduct a detailed gap analysis of AMB’s current 
business model. Recommendations for business model revisions will be developed based on best 
international financial sector practice and will cover the following: 
•  business structure and business areas; 
•  client segmentation and ownership by business units; 
•  value proposition and product ownership;  
•  service delivery channels for each business line including digital banking; 
•  core processes and activities; 
•  support functions and processes; 
•  P&L model and structure; and 
•  business unit level KPIs. 
 
Deliverables by the consulting firm will include: 
•  a report describing findings and recommendations on how to revise and change the 
business model to meet AMB’s future objectives;

•  analysis of each business line and recommendations for change; 
•  recommendations on business structure and operational model;  
•  P&L structure and KPIs for each business line; and 
•  detailed implementation plan with resource estimations. 
 
Output 2: Digital Banking Infrastructure Improvement ($155,000) 
 
5.  AMB has made significant investments in its digital banking infrastructure to date and is 
planning to engage a consulting firm to further enhance its digital banking strategy. The project 
will cover the following: 
•  identification of digital business challenges and priorities; 
•  audit of customer touchpoints, including websites, self-service, ATMs, mobile, email, 
branches, call center, and social media; 
•  analysis of the customer base; 
•  review of technology used to capture and store client data for sales and marketing; 
•  analysis of the technology eco-system to better understand the potential dependencies 
and better define the platform requirements; and 
•  analysis of AMB’s ability to conduct marketing, collect and utilize data, and deliver a 
compelling user experience. 
 
Deliverables by the consulting firm will include: 
•  capability gap analysis of technology, processes and people vs. best practice digital 
experience and data-driven digital marketing for customers; 
•  digital marketing strategy and clear roadmap towards a recommended future state; 
•  recommendation  on  platform  selection  and  definition  of  requirements  for  platform 
implementation; and 
•  training and post-implementation support to user teams. 
 
Output 3: Business Intelligence, Artificial Intelligence and Data Warehousing capacity 
building ($100,000) 
 
6.  AMB is looking to introduce a data-driven decision making system to maximize the use of 
data for smarter decision making, better planning and more empowered employees. Accessing 
and understanding this information will improve AMB’s ability to manage costs and grow margins. 
AMB will engage a consulting firm for the following: 
 
•  review of latest trends in technologies, tools, approaches and methodologies to unlock the 
value in enterprise data assets of an organization;  
•  identification of the specific issues and opportunities within the business, related to the 
application of data science, to guide the implementation of relevant solutions; and 
•  review of reporting requirements and assistance to AMB to establish an optimized data 
architecture to support reporting needs. 
 
Deliverables by the consulting firm will include:  
•  best practice report on the latest trends in business intelligence technology; 
•  design  of  AMB’s  data  management  strategy,  program,  roadmap  and  capabilities 
(governance,  definitions,  policies  &  processes,  quality,  data  analytics  infrastructure, 
architecture, privacy, security, sustained awareness, etc.); 
•  design of enterprise data architecture and management framework for existing as well as 
new data platforms; and

3 
•  business and functional requirements documentation with recommended criteria to select 
a platform with best practice-based functionality.  
 
Output 4: IFRS 9 phase 2 automation and procedural incorporation ($65,000) 
 
7.  This TA component will introduce and update non-performing asset (NPA) and impairment 
processes and automated solutions to ensure IFRS 9 compliance. AMB will engage a consulting 
firm for the following: 
 
•  review of best practices in IFRS 9 implementation, including impairment process and roles 
assignment; 
•  review and update of the IFRS 9 process for AMB; 
•  conduct  a  gap  analysis  between  AMB’s  current  impairment  methodologies  and  the 
requirements of IFRS 9; 
•  enhancement and improvement of existing impairment calculation models in line with 
IFRS 9; and 
•  analysis and definition of business and functional requirements for the best fitting IFRS 9-
compliant solution for AMB. 
 
Deliverables by the consulting firm will include:  
•  best practice report on IFRS 9 implementation; 
•  recommendations on AMB’s IFRS 9 process improvement; 
•  design of enhanced models under IFRS 9, including risk-based rating and pricing models; 
•  business and functional requirement document for the  best fitting IFRS 9-compliant 
solution and potential vendors; 
•  final presentation of provided reports and documents; and 
•  trainings of AMB staff on the new processes, methodologies and approaches. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,170,000, of which (i) $200,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others) and (ii) $400,000 will be 
financed  on  a grant  basis  by  the  Financial  Sector  Development  Partnership  Special  Fund 
(FSDPSF). The remaining $1,570,000 will be financed by AMB as a form of a counterpart to the 
TA. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
9.  Administration of the TA will be delegated to AMB, which will be the executing agency. 
AMB's  Innovation  and  Quality  Unit  will  manage  the  TA  and  has  adequate  management 
capabilities and processes in place to successfully execute the TA. AMB will report internal audit 
findings to ADB on an annual basis. 
 
10.  ADB will disburse the TA funds directly to AMB through an advance payment facility (APF), 
following ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). Financial management assessment has been conducted on AMB and it has adequate 
financial  management  capacity  and  records  keeping  capabilities  to  manage  APF.  TA 
implementation is expected to begin in January 2019 and be completed by 31 December 2022.

4 
11.  The execution of the TA requires the selection of consultants. ADB will monitor the 
selection and procurement steps, check that the use of funds complies with relevant ADB policies, 
and check that outputs for development effectiveness are on track. 
 
12.  AMB and ADB will enter into a TA agreement that sets out the terms and conditions for 
the TA, including AMB's responsibilities in selecting, contracting, and managing the consultants; 
and auditing procedures in a manner acceptable to ADB. The TA agreement will (i) refer to 
relevant agreed selection and contracting frameworks to be used, (ii) confirm ADB's concurrence 
at each relevant stage of the selection process, and (iii) require documentation of the execution 
of the TA; procurement (including consulting services) to be financed by ADB TA Funds will follow 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for 
ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time).  
 
13.  AMB will provide ADB with annual TA progress reports, including information on the 
following: 
(i)  identification of solutions and consultation with ADB; 
(ii)  preparation  of  implementation  plans,  including  the  development, testing,  and 
rollout of new products and services and staff training; and 
(iii)  execution, performance tracking, and monitoring of the implementation plans.

14.  Consulting services. In addition to the expertise criteria set out in the applicable TORs, 
in order for an individual consultant or a consulting firm to qualify as consultant, the following 
eligibility criteria shall be met:  
(i)  a consulting firm will be incorporated in an ADB member country;  
(ii)  an individual consultant, either engaged individually or through a consulting firm, 
will be a citizen of one of the ADB member countries; 
(iii)  a consultant will be competent and qualified for services in accordance with the 
terms of the TA Agreement to be entered into with AMB;  
(iv)  an individual consultant shall not be named on ADB's Sanctions List or sanctioned 
by ADB pursuant to ADB's Integrity Principles and Guidelines (2015, as amended 
from time to time);  
(v)  a consulting firm, including its personnel, shall not be named on ADB's Sanctions 
List or owned or controlled by a person or a legal entity that is named on the 
International Sanctions List or sanctioned by ADB pursuant to ADB's Integrity 
Principles and Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time); and 
(vi)  an  individual  consultant  shall  not  be  a  representative  or  an  employee  of  a 
government organization, or a related party of AMB, its subsidiaries or its staff.

5 
 
15.  AMB will select consulting firms through Quality Based Selection (QBS) and will use either 
time-based contracts or lump sum contracts, depending on the scope of the assignment. AMB 
will not use any ADB TA Funds for payment of any applicable taxes, and shall be solely liable for 
payment of any such taxes from its own funds.  
 
E.  Governance  
 
16.  ADB has carried out a procurement capacity assessment of AMB which found AMB’s 
procurement  procedures  to  be  satisfactory.  Integrity  due  diligence  has  been  conducted  in 
accordance with ADB's Integrity Due Diligence Guidelines for Nonsovereign Operations as part 
of PSOD’s due diligence for the loan and equity investment that was approved in September 
2017.2 The most recent IDD review by OAI was conducted in April 2018. ADB’s review of the 
ownership structure does not give ADB cause to believe that such entity has been established, 
or is being used for cross-border tax evasion, money laundering, or terrorism financing in the 
jurisdictions involved in the investment.  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of the technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $400,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development 
Partnership Special Fund; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$200,000 on a grant basis to Ameriabank CJSC for Capacity Building for Ameriabank, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
